Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: If you quote me, give what I said.
I have the paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: I am not going to take any paper. Quote what I said. Get the Official Report if you are going to quote me.

I have a perfect right to quote from a daily paper in this Dáil. Let the Deputy deny it. We will leave it to the Official Report afterwards. “The President's statement was delivered on a motion to restrict discussion, and no excuse whatever has been put forward as to why the discussion should be restricted. The recital of the long list of incidents which everyone in the House regretted did not justify bringing in a Bill of this kind. The ordinary law was quite sufficient to deal with the matters referred to by the President.... He believed that if they were there five or ten years hence, there would be Bills like this one introduced if the present state of affairs was allowed to continue.”
These are not the words that the Minister attributed to the Deputy.
Absolutely.
There is an “if” there.
What is the distinction?
The Minister quoted half a sentence as he usually does.
Perhaps the Deputy will explain it afterwards.
The Minister has been found out, and that is what is annoying him.

“He believed that if they were there five or ten years hence there would be Bills like this one introduced if the present state of affairs is allowed to continue,” the present state of affairs being that we are functioning under a Constitution which enshrines adult suffrage, proportional representation and trial by jury. “He believed that the gentlemen on the opposite benches ought to know the real lines on which to proceed, but they preferred to imitate the activities of Hamar Greenwood.”

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: Yes. Now will you apologise?
Certainly not.
You have not the decency.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: You do not mind how you twist and wriggle.

I am the only one who has been interrupted. One of the activities of the present Government was bringing in this Bill, and we are told that this activity is on a par with the activities of Hamar Greenwood. Now it does not matter what the Deputy means. No one knows what he means, but what I am concerned with is what the people to whom he knows he is talking, think he means. I am concerned with what he said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: The people will know what to think.
On a point of order, if a Deputy deliberately misquotes another Deputy, and is then compelled to admit that he has done so, is he not supposed to withdraw the misquotation?
Is the Deputy serious about that point of order?
I am quite serious.
Let the Deputy deny this quotation when it comes to his turn.
He is denying it now.
The Deputy has not denied the accuracy of that quotation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: I deny what you attributed to me as what I said.
I am not on that. I am not concerned with what you meant, but I am concerned with what you said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: What you would like to attribute to me is all that you are concerned with.
Deputies must allow the Minister to proceed.

“The arguments that would be put up to young men to join the organisations mentioned”—that is Saor Eire, Cumann na mBán, the I.R.A.—I am quoting again from Deputy de Valera's speech—“would be a repetition of those put up by Mr. Blythe and Mr. Mulcahy when they were asking the young men of the country to join the I.R.B.” What is the plain meaning of that? The plain meaning of that to anybody who knows English is that there is as good reason for joining these organisations which shot Curtin and Ryan as for joining the organisations that were formed here to put the British out of the country. What else does that mean? What do you think the gunmen will take out of it? They will take out of it this, that they have the same right to shoot now as in the old days the Volunteers had the right to shoot Hamar Greenwood and the British. That is all they can take out of it. That was one part of the Deputy's speech, such as it was. As I said before, the speech was divided into two parts. But there was another part. He then went on and announced that the only authority in this country—he gave his allegiance to majority rule—was the authority of the Dáil, something for which we have been striving for the last seven or eight years.

MainHeading.P: He said that the only authority in this country that had the right to take life was the authority established by this Dáil. That was the second part of his speech. If he had made one or the other I would know where Deputy de Valera stands, but he made both in the same speech. As a rule his timing was not just as it was yesterday. He makes a speech to-day and enunciates one set of principles, and he makes a speech to-morrow and enunciates another set. Yesterday he came along, and in the same speech enunciated two quite different sets of principles. If the authority in this Dáil is the only authority that can take life, if the authority in the Dáil is the only legitimate authority in the country, why talk of the methods of Hamar Greenwood, and why say that the men outside have the same right to organise against this Dáil as Mulcahy and Blythe had to organise against Greenwood? That is what he did say.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: That is an untruth, and it is known to be an untruth.

I am not concerned with what you say is your opinion of me. I will quote your words again, and I challenge you to say these are not in the Official Report. I have not seen the Official Report, but I listened to you, and I have the newspaper report here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: Do not be trying your little petty attorney tricks here now.
That comes very well from the most inveterate pettifogger that ever cursed this country.
That comes very well from a man who was mulcted in £500 damages for lying.

Get up and talk afterwards. Do not get hysterical. You do not frighten me. Leave that to Deputy Boland now. He knows more about it than you do. This is what Deputy de Valera denies: “The argument that would be put up to young men to-day to join the organisations mentioned would be a repetition of those put up by Mr. Blythe and Mr. Mulcahy when they were asking the young men of the country to join the I.R.B.” Does Deputy de Valera deny he used these words?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: I do not deny them at all.
That is enough. I want to say this. I have been in public life since 1921. Since 1921 I have had contact in one way or another with Deputy de Valera.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. de Valera Mr. de Valera
Speaker.P: Not very much.

Not much; a little too much for you. That has been his consistent line since 1921. He will blow hot and cold. On the one hand, he will play up to the gunmen and on the other hand he will mouth morality, and that is what has left this country as it is. Remember this, and this is why I went on the speeches of Deputies Anthony and Morrissey—that bacteria will only breed if the atmosphere is right—in a fetid atmosphere only. It is that sort of pettifogging, double dealing, confusing morality, confusing constitutionalism and physical force that has created the atmosphere that makes it possible for the sort of bacteria to breed that was responsible for the murder of Curtin and Ryan, and if there is one man in this country more than another who was responsible for that it is the Leader of the Party opposite. I say that deliberately and I have been in public life and watching him since 1921. He has injected into this country a culture which can only cause decay and disintegration. From that point of view the speeches made to-day by Deputies Morrissey and Anthony were the first sign of fresh air and sunlight which are going to dissipate them in this country. What the Dáil and the country are entitled to is this: they are entitled to know on which leg Deputy de Valera stands. He often tells us that he is the leader of the second biggest Party in the Dáil, and we hear that he is going to be the leader of the next Government. If he is, he will have responsibility, and what this country is entitled to know beforehand is which set of principles he is going to invoke when challenged by the gunmen, as challenged he will be undoubtedly. That is what the plain people of the country are entitled to hear, and they have not heard it yet. I honestly would rather if Deputy de Valera had made a speech yesterday backing the gunmen than the pettifogging double-dealing speech he made.
And then you would have made the same speech to-day.

It has been said that if we pass this Bill and take these powers there is going to be confusion, civil war and disturbance in the country. Deputy O'Connell said that. I also heard that from the opposite benches.
From the Minister for Local Government.
Do you think so? I put this to Deputy Lemass. He said yesterday that the organisations in question would only welcome this Bill, that it would give them an accession of strength.
That is what the Bill is designed for.
Was that his opinion always?
Yes.

This report may be wrong also. It is not from the “Irish Press” but from the “Irish Independent” of August 24th, 1931. The Deputy remembers addressing an aeridheacht at Roebuck House. In Roebuck House he was inspired by Cumann na mBán, the gunmen, and the rest of them. This is what he said:

For a long time the Government had been deliberately at work to produce a situation that would justify new repressive legislation. Openly and secretly they had been trying to foment unrest and produce all that would justify them in arming themselves with new powers that would enable them to appear before the people as strong men defying anarchy. If they got from the people approval of this repressive legislation at a general election or otherwise they would use that legislation ruthlessly to stamp out the last vestige of militant Republicanism.

MainHeading.P: This is the Deputy who informed us yesterday that if this Bill were passed it would mean an accession of strength to militant republicanism. We have heard from Deputies opposite that there is going to be trouble. I draw attention to this, particularly Deputy O'Connell's attention. We hear a lot about repressive legislation, the fact being that there has been no repressive legislation here. There was one Public Safety Act. It never operated, but particular portions of it were on the Statute Book for 18 months in 1927. That Act provided for military courts, and while that legislation was there there was not a shot fired or a word said. The militant republicans remained quiet, and so far as the ordinary citizen was concerned it might as well not have been on the Statute Book. There was never any necessity to put it into operation. One month after the Act was repealed, or after the section of it which provided for the establishment of military courts was repealed, a juryman was shot and a witness murdered. Since then that sort of thing has been continued. Deputy O'Connell need not be alarmed. There will be no civil war when this Bill passes.

Speaker.P: I never suggested there would.

There is nobody there to be provoked by this. The one attribute of the men outside who have been challenging the State for the last three years is that they will take no risks whatever—everything must be dead safe. Any little brat with a gun can intimidate a civilian. Once people stoop to that there is no way to protect that civilian except to have two detectives, one on each side of him, or to make it too dangerous. Deputy O'Connell need not be afraid. This Bill will not cause confusion. This Bill, I make bold to say, will solve the problem with very little necessity to operate it. I go further and say that if we had more speeches like those of Deputies Morrissey and Anthony, showing public spirit, that civilians could not be cowed, that there was a real love of democracy and good European blood in the civilians of this country, we would never need the Bill at all.

Yesterday we had some revelations from the Minister for Justice. He mentioned that there were several members of this Party in touch with Russia. He mentioned the leader of this Party, Deputy Lemass and Deputy Aiken and said that in 1925 a mission was sent to Russia which included a member of this Party and for some unexplained reason he did not mention who the member was. I happened to be the member of this Party who went to Russia in 1925. That is correct. The fact that a mission went to Russia in 1925 has been urged as a proof that this Party or the members of it have been associated with Communist activities. The Minister for Local Government made a big mistake when he said that the first Irishman to send a deputation to Russia was the leader of this Party. He was corrected by Deputy MacEntee shortly afterwards and reminded that the Provisional Government of which he was a member sent an envoy to meet representatives of the Soviet in London and we have not heard that these men have been tainted with Communism.
And we have not heard a thing of what it was about from Deputy MacEntee, or we will not hear anything.

The fact was that you were prepared to make contracts with the “tainted goods.” The President, the Minister for Local Government and other members of the Government in 1917 were members of the Sinn Fein Republic.
Tell us what you were doing in Russia.

I am quite prepared to tell the House what I was doing in Russia. I followed a line that was followed by the Irish Nationalists from the days of Elizabeth, when O'Donnell went to Spain to seek aid against the British, up to the time Casement went in the last war. Casement went to seek the aid of England's enemies to smash England. I went on the same mission and followed the same line, but the Russians were too busy minding their own business to mind me. I failed completely. In all our history our friends were always England's enemies. We could not get help from the Boers, but we sent help to the Boers. I was not old enough at the time, but we did send Irishmen. There is a member of this establishment who actually fought to show the age-long hatred to Britain. I went to Russia in the vain hope that we would get Russian people to weaken the power of our enemies, and I am proud of what I did. I have a document issued by an organisation of which the Minister, and I am almost sure the President, were members in 1917. I have never heard him called a Muscovite, a Bolshevik, or a Communist, as he called others yesterday, because he was a party to this letter. This document was issued by the Election Committee of Dr. Pat McCartan in 1917, who was a Sinn Fein candidate for South Armagh about the same time as the President was elected in Kilkenny. It has printed in big letters: “McCartan to the representatives of the Russian people, London,” and is headed: “Trotsky, the most respectable citizen in the world.”“Trotsky insists that England shall allow the people of Ireland, India, etc., to determine their own form of government.” Why did he refer to Russia? Because Dr. Pat McCartan explained the position of Ireland to the Russians. I am not going to bother you about what follows. The President is well known to be a very religious person. No one would ever attempt to call him a Communist, but he sent his agents around this country.
I did not draw up that document.

You were a member of the Committee, and I am not going to tell you that you are a Bolshevist. The really serious aspect in this matter that has been presented to this House, and which the Government pretends they consider serious, is that there is a taint of Communism in this movement. I am quite satisfied that the Government would never attempt to bring in this measure if they were not able to work up this stunt that there was a foreign influence at work. I believe they would be quite satisfied to use the ordinary machinery they have at their disposal. It is quite adequate to deal with the situation, but they have got up the stunt of failure, as a foreign delegate— apparently somebody else I do not know anything about—has succeeded. They got the twelve apostles apparently trained in Moscow to spread the gospel in a country like Ireland, which is full of individualists.

I do not suppose there is any country in Europe since the Land Commission began to work where there are so many small proprietors. To think that any serious people are going to be humbugged by the suggestion that Communism is going to take root here is preposterous. It will not work with me, and I think that anyone will not be deluded by this well-staged display of gunmen. I have a grievance too. I do not see why I should not have protection. I am entitled as a Deputy to be protected as well as some of the people I see protected, and I want to take this occasion to protest against my exclusion.

MainHeading.P: About three years ago there was a motion asking for the revision of the cases of certain prisoners, and more particularly of certain people who were on the run in Ireland at the time. I spoke in the debate and mentioned what I knew to be a fact, that there were so many men on the run in whose case the slate had not been wiped clean that we were going to create a situation in this country that would inevitably lead to a state of disorder, and that the Government would do what I said these were trying to do, on the eve of an election, to stampede the country into a belief that civil war was about to start again. I condemn gunmen. I always condemned them. I did not like them even at the time the present Minister for Local Government was organising them. That is in the old days in the time of the British. I never liked them. When a document of his was captured suggesting the poisoning of British troops it appalled me. I never liked murders and I accept the authority of this place for the simple reason that it is a fact. It is a hard fact, and there is no getting over it. I have accepted the authority as the only authority in this country. I say give these people a chance, and wipe the slate clean, instead of harrowing them, as you did for instance, in the case of Con Healy, a man I knew well who was harried for about two years. To show that he was not a criminal he could get shelter in any house in his own area in County Cork. When the C.I.D. came after him they told people if they caught him they were going to shoot him. The result was that Healy, being a spirited man, carried a gun, and when the police came he fired but he did not hit them. When charging him with this offence they charged him with firing on the police, and they gave him five years in jail.

When we came here in 1927 we made a genuine attempt to settle this question and to have the Republican movement conducted on strictly constitutional lines. We made a special appeal to the Government to wipe the slate and to give the people a chance. They never did it. I deliberately say now— I am not doing this for Party purposes —that you have done this deliberately, as Deputy Lemass said last night, to cover up all the blunders you have made in other lines—your Shannon scheme and other things. I am sorry they have been a financial failure.

Speaker.P: They are not.

They are. They were to cost £5,000,000 and they will cost £12,000,000. That is only a difference of £7,000,000 or £8,000,000. That does not, of course, count with the President. He talks in big amounts. We have not heard much about the Drumm battery lately. I believe it is a failure, too. I did not study this Bill, but I read some of the provisions about the military court. I shall give a little experience of mine in this connection. Towards the end of the civil war, I was in Mountjoy Prison. There was a boy of eighteen years of age named O'Rourke there. He is dead now. He was brought out to face one of these tribunals, and he was beaten senseless and thrown into a cell. Deputy Doctor Ryan happened to be a prisoner in Mountjoy at the same time. He attended the boy and tried to bring him round. When he had restored him, to some extent, he asked why did they do this. The boy replied: “I do not know. They told me I was going to be shot in the morning.” The Doctor asked: “Were you tried?” The boy replied: “I don't know, except that the beating I got was a trial.” That boy was taken out in a bruised and beaten condition and shot dead.
They called it an execution.

I certainly hope that nothing like that is going to happen. I know people who, I believe, are still connected with that organisation, the I.R.A. I have told them privately what I thought of them, and I shall tell them publicly what I think of them. They have, unknowingly, gone from the moral plane right down to the criminal status. Without their own knowledge, they have gone gradually down, and that is where they are now. But I certainly say the chief blame is on the Government, and if they had taken the genuine advice they got here four years ago they would not have this state of affairs. I am afraid it was deliberately done in order that they might be kept in office. I say that fully and honestly believing it.

Yesterday I made my protest against the closure motion. To-day I should like to elaborate my reasons for doing so. I had two reasons. In the first place, I had not had an opportunity of consulting my constituents and getting their mandate for my vote on this Bill. In the second place, the Government themselves did not give the people an opportunity to afford them the mandate which I hold they would have got if they had asked the people for it. When I was a very young member of this House—in July, 1927—a Public Safety Bill was brought in, following one of the most regrettable incidents—as they have been referred to here—that have occurred in this country, the murder of the Vice-President of the Executive Council. A Public Safety Bill was brought in, as I held at that time, under panic conditions. We had debates on that Public Safety Bill on all fours with the debate we had here to-day. We were told about what would happen in three or four years. We were told that that measure would drive the people to revolution and all sorts of things. We were told, too—I want to emphasise this—that certain powers given to the Government would be so abused by servants of the Government that innocent people all over the country would be indicted out of private party spite. I was a young member of the House on that occasion. I suffered a good deal for having supported that Public Safety Bill, although I did my best to take the objectionable features out of it. Some of my amendments were accepted by the Government. In the few years that that Act remained on the Statute Book, I did not know of one instance where an innocent man was arraigned or brought before a tribunal because of party or personal considerations. That Public Safety Act created a furore all over the country, but, while it remained on the Statute Book, there was no injustice done to an innocent man because of it. I am prepared to go to my constituents to-morrow with a much greater sense of security after supporting this Bill to-day than I could go to my constituents a month after voting for the Public Safety Bill. If I might sum up the situation so far as opposition to this Bill is concerned, the mildest speaker, so far as I can understand, is prepared to give control of this State on a fifty-fifty basis—fifty per cent. to the gunman and fifty per cent. to the Government. That is as far as they will go. How can we run a Government under these conditions? No matter what Government is in power—I am not speaking for the personnel of the Government before me; I am speaking for the personnel of any Government which is given authority— that Government must get a hundred per cent. control of the law and order of the State. Otherwise there could be no law or order in the country.

MainHeading.P: It has been said here that for seven hundred years the people of this country have been fighting for freedom. It has been suggested—possibly with a certain measure of truth—that we have not got enough freedom at the moment, and that, perhaps, for seven hundred years more we shall have to fight on until whoever is then alive is satisfied with our measure of freedom. I would be untrue to all my principles of life if I did not vote for this Bill. I have been an upholder of majority rule all my life and an opponent of the gun. I believe that whatever extensions of freedom we will have secured in the future will be gained by constitutional methods. Nothing that occurred in this country in recent years has convinced me that I was wrong in adopting constitutional methods long ago.

Speaker.P: What did you do with the guns you brought in in 1914?
I never used a gun in my life, and I never allowed anybody over whom I had control to use a gun which had a cartridge in it.
Who sent the guns in 1914?

I shall tell you that. I never was a believer in the gun. When the Deputy was at one end of the gun, I was at the wrong end of it, fighting the gun. I was not afraid to go out. I was at the wrong end of the gun the Deputy held, and I was not afraid to be at the wrong end of it.
What were you going to do with the guns?
Deputy O'Hanlon must be allowed to make his speech.
I shall not have an opportunity of making a speech. If I had, I would reply to him all right.
I stand here as a person whose past is an open book to anybody who knows the history of the past twenty or twenty-five years.
You were a twister from the beginning.

I never used a gun, and when the gentleman who interrupted me held a gun I was at the wrong end of it. I could give a little more history if I liked. There were men who held guns and who, I think, were not less patriotic than I was. But I did not believe in the gun. There were men who honestly believed that by the gun they could get a bigger measure of liberty than I could get by other means. But that is not my point. I would be false to my nature if I did not support this Bill, which is in conformity with my public actions during my whole life. I am sorry my friend has interjected a rather unpleasant thing, because I could tell something about the gun which would not please him.
Better get it all out.

I always fought for the liberty of the people, and it is for the liberty of the people I am fighting to-day. I want to know whose liberty is at stake in this Bill. For whose liberty are those who oppose the Bill fighting? Is it not for the liberty of the potential murderer?
And the liberty of the assassin!

There is another principle being fought for. There is the principle of free speech fought for by those who oppose this Bill. What manner of speech has been going on during the last few months? People talk about our fighting for freedom for 700 years. This country has been Christianised for 1,500 years. Are we to stand by and let Asiatic rats come in and take the Christianity from our people which they have held for 1,500 years? If this Bill was designed for no other purpose than to guard against that I would say that purpose alone would justify this Bill.

MainHeading.P: There are other reasons for this Bill. I opposed the Public Safety Act because it was an emergency and panic Act. I was justified to a certain extent in opposing it on these grounds. I believed a week ago that this Bill was simply going to be an emergency measure like the Public Safety Act. I found on the morning that I came up here, and only then, that this Bill was going to take the form of a new clause in the Constitution, and that the Government were taking powers now in this Bill for themselves and their successors, powers which I hold they made a great mistake in not taking years ago. I say that with all the knowledge. I have of the use the Government has already made of their powers. They had powers under the Public Safety Act to do things and acts of injustice were not tolerated. I hold that every Government in this extraordinary period of the world's history should have in its Constitution, or by some other means, power to deal with people who want to subvert the State, and who want to destroy law and order. That seems to be the new policy all over. The Muscovite policy, as the President said, has permeated the nations of the world which have not power to deal with these Russian rats and everybody else who puts up his head to subvert the State, destroy law and order and kill religion, no matter what religion so long as it is a Christian religion. That is what is being done here and in other countries. This country would not be doing right if it did not take powers to deal with these people in the future.

I have two grievances against the Government in connection with this matter. One is that they did not consult the people openly and get a mandate they could stand over. The second is that they did not think of having powers like these incorporated in the Constitution before to-day. I am going back to my constituency tomorrow with the full knowledge that not one half per cent. of the people who voted for me at the last election will find fault with me for the vote I am about to give to-day, but I complain that I have not had the opportunity of saying to my constituents: “I went up to the Dáil and did what you expected me to do.” I am satisfied that the vote I am about to give is the right vote, but I regret that I did not get a mandate from my people before I came up here. I am quite satisfied that this Bill should have been brought in years ago.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Sullivan) John Marcus O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: This Bill has been attacked. The principal attack, as made by those who for some time have been accustomed to accept our Constitution, is that it is unconstitutional; that it interferes with the liberties under the Constitution, described by us as democratic, as giving every member of the public the right to express his political views, as giving the means to the people, if they so desire, to put any Government they like into power; and that that Constitution is being abrogated. Nothing of the kind. This Bill is being introduced as an Article in the Constitution because it is necessary for the preservation of the rights already enshrined in the Constitution. It is necessary because, as I think most people in this House ought to know, that in the last few months a campaign has been growing or threatening to grow beyond all control, a campaign which, if not dealt with and dealt with quickly, would in a short time be beyond the control of this or any other Government, a campaign to make the rights of the people absolutely nugatory. What is the good of having rights enshrined in the Constitution guaranteeing the liberties of the individual when for political motives ordinary individuals can be taken out of their houses and shot, when the ordinary man can be terrorised and prevented from giving expression to his political views?

People talk of elections, but everybody knows that there are a number of places at this moment where the free expression of opinion by the electorate would be almost impossible. If that state of affairs was allowed to continue, those who had experience in this country for the last ten years must know perfectly well that that terrorism would completely dominate the country. It is said that this Bill interferes with the rights of the people guaranteed by the Constitution. This is the only way we can see to guarantee to the ordinary law-abiding citizen the rights that are his by the Constitution. If these powers the Government is asking for are not granted or if they are not effective, then the Constitution still remains, but it remains, so far as 99 per cent. of the people are concerned, a dead letter. It remains a dead letter, not because people's rights are interfered with by the Government, but because the people's lives are interfered with by the ordinary gun bully.

MainHeading.P: People seem to suggest that there is no evidence of unrest demanding a Bill of this kind. I know perfectly well the extraordinary difficulty of convincing some people when they demand evidence. We know that when dumps were discovered the suggestion was made that they were planted there by the C.I.D. for the purpose of helping Government propaganda. These dumps were openly acknowledged afterwards by the organisation from which they were captured, but there was no withdrawal of the charge made here. What is the situation we are faced with? I have met ordinary people from the country in the last few months and they have been more perturbed as to the future in store for this country than even in the year 1922. In some respects, so far as the potentialities of danger are concerned, I think that the situation if not dealt with immediately will be more serious than it was in 1922. At that period you had two big parties contending and there was all the likelihood of compliance with the will of the majority. What is the situation to-day? If the position that has developed in the last couple of months is allowed to go on unchecked, what will be the situation? You may talk of Soviets or republics or anything you like, but is it not the position that this country is going to be split up so far as control is concerned into a number of parishes or half parishes and each parish or half parish will be under the control of a local committee of men with the guns in their hands? That is the situation—dismemberment of the country in that sense, a complete lack of control, a situation created that neither this nor any other Government that may succeed it can deal with.

That is the situation we have to try to prevent from developing beyond control. Deputy O'Connell told us that he has no sympathy, except with the law-abiding citizens, and that he does not want full freedom for the gunman.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. O'Connell Mr. T.J. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Any freedom.

Any freedom for the gunman. Unfortunately that is what the gunman has. I may say that a situation is developing, and in some places has developed, in which the only person with political freedom is the gunman. The ordinary citizens in certain neighbourhoods have not that freedom any longer. The story told by Deputy Anthony that people were afraid to give information because he was seen passing with a gun is typical. We know that strangers in certain parts of the country will not be shown the way if anything disagreeable has occurred in the neighbourhood. People are afraid and are already terrorised. That was so a couple of months ago. The danger is that if it is not grappled with it will become universal. There is no good in Deputy O'Connell and other Deputies saying that they have no sympathy with these things, if their detestation and their hatred of these crimes are not translated into current cash, into something effective. That is why I object to the attitude taken up by Deputy O'Connell on this occasion, and on more occasions than this. So far as expressions of sympathy go, everything is splendid. It is only when it comes to giving expression and practical force to these intentions that we part company. There is no good being sympathetic with a person who has been murdered. There is no good being sympathetic with people who are being terrorised if effective measures are not taken to deal with the matter.

It has been suggested, I think, from the opposite benches that the ordinary law is there. The whole contention of the Government is, and that contention is borne out by the facts as they prevail in the country at present, that the ordinary law has broken down, that it has proved ineffective to deal with these matters. The ordinary law and the ordinary tribunals are not capable of giving to the citizen the protection to which he is entitled. It is because that is so that this Bill is necessary. Therefore nothing could be more absurd than answering arguments in favour of the Bill by suggesting that the ordinary law is there. The ordinary law, as anyone who does not deliberately shut his eyes to facts knows, has broken down. The jury system has broken down. It was threatened. It has broken down. There was a certain amount of partiality in some cases. Leave that alone. On the whole that would not have been unduly effective. It has broken down because juries are terrorised, and because witnesses are terrorised.

MainHeading.P: There are portions of the country in which already people are afraid to be seen speaking to the ordinary civic guard. Why? Is it because these ordinary citizens do not respect the law? Is it because they are not friendly to the Guards? It is not. It is because already they are beginning to be afraid of the consequences. That is affecting not merely the administration of the law where quasi-political crimes are concerned, but it is affecting the ordinary administration of the law in some cases. That is one reason, but not the only one, why we are anxious that the administration of this particular Bill should be entirely removed from the ordinary administration of the law. As a result of the way in which political crime has been fostered in this country for a number of years, the ordinary administration of the law is in danger of being contaminated. We want to keep the two rigidly apart. Not merely that, but, as the President pointed out in his speech, in the circumstances that are necessary we want, when a situation of this kind arises, to have a tribunal that will not be open and that the people with whom it deals cannot hope that it will be open to any kind of terrorism.

Incidents have been referred to. It is not one murder, two murders or three murders. That is not the important thing. It is that these murders, either of Superintendent Curtin, Carroll or Ryan, and various other attempted murders, are symptoms of a widespread conspiracy. That is the seriousness of it. It is not the murder, appalling as it may be, it is the fact that they are symptoms of a disease that threatens the very existence of this country. That is the reason why it is necessary to deal with them. They are not isolated events, and anyone who refers to them merely as incidents ignores the real facts of the situation. They are incidents by which a certain number of people are attempting to arrogate to themselves the right to dictate to the people of this country what political opinions they will effectively hold, what political opinions they will give expression to, and what form of Government they will live under. These incidents, lightly referred to here occasionally, are symptoms of the gradually growing success of that policy in the last couple of months. The immunity that these people have enjoyed, the widespread conspiracy evidenced by it in most of the counties of the Saorstát—dreadful evidence of it in some cases—that conspiracy has been going on and not a single step could be taken under the present laws to bring to justice the people who were guilty of these crimes or who instigated them.

That is the situation that the House and the country have to face. The country knows it well. I met many people, even to-day, and they told me that it was with a sigh of relief they greeted the First Reading of this Bill, and the majority that it received. They felt that it was the duty of the Government to introduce it, and that if the Government had been guilty of anything it was guilty of delay in not introducing a measure of the kind before. That was the main criticism I heard. I cannot share that criticism. We waited, and we were as slow as possible before we introduced a measure of this kind. Certainly it has been borne upon every member of the Government for the last three months that unless this situation was taken in hands quickly it would get out of hand. That is no exaggeration. Any one who is familiar with the history of revolutionary movements in this country knows the speed which things of that kind can attain. I put it to Deputies in every Party that there is a duty not merely to Party, but a duty to the country.

Deputy O'Connell and Deputy de Valera spoke of getting at the causes— the economic causes. It is quite true, of course, that these people can appeal to the man out of work and to the man in hard circumstances. These doctrines that are being preached can make such an appeal. Even the revolutionary element with guns in their hands can make that appeal, and in some cases can make it successfully. Is Deputy O'Connell's knowledge of the revolutionary movement such that this thing can wait until the economic system of this country, as he calls it, is tackled in a fully revolutionary manner? The thing is absurd. There would be no economic situation or anything else if this thing was allowed to get out of hand. It could get out of hand in a couple of months if not dealt with. We have been accused of introducing this measure to make Party capital out of it. I ask anyone who listened to the speeches on both sides of the House, both for and against this measure, and I ask the public to judge, where was the appeal to popular sentiment? Where was the effort to get the support of the ordinary unthinking public? On the side of the unfortunate prisoner, as Deputy Anthony put it very clearly, why is there all the practical sympathy? It is practical sympathy I am interested in, and not in expressions of lip sympathy. Why is it that all the practical sympathy of certain Parties in this House is always with the malefactor and never for the malefactor's victim? Why is there always a shrinking from taking steps to protect the innocent? Why is it that all the pleas for every tittle of the law, every little refinement, every little rule of evidence have to be thrown on the side of those who are guilty, of those who are trying to ruin the country, while nothing is to be done for the protection of the ordinary citizen? That is the situation we have to confront.

We expect to get very little Party capital out of this. We knew it was our duty as a Government to prevent this situation from developing or else to clear out. There is no other alternative open to us. We did not expect to get any great or enthusiastic support from a large number of people in this country because we proposed it. If we do get any Party advantage out of it—and I make a present of this to the Deputies opposite—it is because of the attitude adopted in this House by the Labour Party and the Fianna Fáil Party. That is the only reason that we could get any advantage out of this measure. As to the measure itself, it is not the kind of measure that any Government would care to introduce. It was introduced only because it was completely and absolutely necessary, because there was, if you like, a half state of war in this country. It was a one-sided war in which all the shooting, all the activities, all the deploying of armies, everything, could be done by one side, and the people and the people's Government, the Dáil, were completely bound up, tied up, and they had nothing to do but to stand bound hand and foot looking on at the destruction of the country and the institutions of the country. That is the situation.

It is because we take steps in the only possible way to protect the rights of the Constitution, and to see that those rights granted by the Constitution are not violated, are not mere paper, to see that they are a reality, that we are accused of scrapping the Constitution, but you may scrap the Constitution in reality and still let every Article of it stand. That is the attitude adopted by those who uphold this measure. This Constitution can be violated, can become a dead letter so far as the ordinary citizen is concerned. The Articles all remain sacrosanct, but the Constitution becomes a dead letter. Deputies have only to think over that fully to realise it. We try to prevent that occurring. That is the reason I ask the support of the Dáil for this particular measure.

Two main things are aimed at. The first is to deal effectively with crime. Extended powers are necessary for that. If we try to limit the powers contained in this Bill in order to safeguard against the possibility of abuse of power, anybody familiar with the administration of the law or familiar with the drawing up of Bills must realise quickly that you may kill the Bill, that a safeguard to guard against an imaginary evil that may spring up from ill-will on the part of the Executive or a deliberate perversion of the law by the Executive, will only have the effect of killing the Bill altogether. We undoubtedly seek tremendous powers in this Bill. We found it impossible to limit these powers because we felt that any limitation of them would probably mean interference with the proper and effective working of this engine to guarantee to the ordinary citizen all ordinary rights.

The second portion of the Bill deals with the question of propaganda. Does anybody suggest that there has been any undue interference with the free expression of opinion in this country? I know no country in which there is less interference by those in authority, with the expression of opinion than there is in this country. Many people are shocked not because we interfere with the expression of opinion but that we allow so much free expression of opinion, especially of certain doctrines. Somebody said that this is a Bill to prevent the expression of political opinion. It is nothing of the kind. This is a Bill, I quite admit, to prevent incitement to crime. Everybody knows — I wonder does Deputy O'Connell and others of his Party who are voting against this Bill deny it—that there has been plenty of incitement to crime in certain papers in the country for the last six months. I do not think he can deny that. This is a Bill to see that incitement to crime of that kind can be dealt with. We are asked why they were not dealt with up to the present. Again experience has shown us that the ordinary law is not capable of dealing with that particular state of affairs. It is no good to tell us to appeal to the ordinary law when our whole case is that the ordinary law is incapable of dealing with the situation that now exists.

After the passage of this Bill the expression of political opinion, so long as there is no appeal to force to back that up, will remain as free as it was before. Without the passing of this Bill Deputies know that in a very short time there would be very little free expression of opinion in this country even so far as this House is concerned. They know how the affair started with jurymen. They were visited. They were told in quite a calm, gentle way, of course, with no element of threat— far be it from anybody to threaten them!—that certain people were being tried. That was merely brought to their notice, and we know what happened afterwards. That was the first step. We all know of the visits to Deputies in the last couple of weeks when they were asked to give their opinions on this Bill. We all know what the visit to Deputies would be the preliminary to. The way in which Deputies have reacted to that threat is certainly one of the bright spots in a very black situation. Not one Deputy has been influenced by action of that kind in the attitude he has taken or will take on this Bill. That is a very hopeful sign, not merely as far as this House is concerned, but so far as the country as a whole is concerned. These visits were merely to see what Deputies' views were! Advice was given that Deputies should be visited and have views placed before them. As a visitor, you did nothing illegal. You said nothing. You only called on your Deputy. Who was better entitled to visit a Deputy than a constituent to find out how he intended to vote on this Bill?” Quite so. As I said, that is how the matter started with jurymen. We had a case quoted by the President in which a number of men visited a Limerick body because they passed a resolution condemning the murder of Superintendent Curtin. They said: “This will suffice for the present.” Is that to be the case also with Deputies—a polite request: “Do not vote for this horrid Bill; that will be enough for the present”?

As I say, the responsibility unfortunately is, first and foremost, on the Government to put before the people their view of what the situation is, and not merely what the situation is but what are the potentialities of the situation. I say that because I have been convinced, especially within the last three months, that there is a situation here that, in a very short time, would mean that each half parish in this country would be completely under the rule of the local little knot of people with the gun. I ask the Deputies who are not too much committed to Party ties whether their experience of this country in the past does not appear to be that the Irish people will not succumb to Communism in this country. People are too much attached to the old principles! I wonder how long they would stand it? What real active opposition would they be able to put up against, not the peaceful visit telling them what views they are to adopt, but against the much more effective visit which has taken place in this country by people with guns in their hands?

I say under these conditions there is no future for this country, under this or any other Government, because no Government would be possible if a situation of that kind were allowed to get out of hand. This Bill has been introduced as being the only means we can use to cope with that situation. We trust and hope it will deal with that situation. We introduced it because we are the Government whose mission it is to look to the safety of the country. This Bill is necessary, not for the safety of the Government, not for the safety of Government officials, of Government servants, such as police and soldiers, but it is still more necessary for the safety and the protection of the lives and liberties of the ordinary citizens of the country.

Speaker.P: I object to this Bill as an attack upon constitutional action and constitutional methods. It was asserted by a Deputy from these benches yesterday that if there is a sincere desire to promote the peace of this country on the part of the Government the removal of the Oath of Allegiance to King George might perhaps help to foster that so much desired peace. The Minister for Justice thereupon said: “If I remove that oath will you give me any guarantee that the people who resort to physical force will come in?” I am merely paraphrasing the Minister's words. That rhetorical challenge on the part of the Minister for Justice is a fair example of the specious methods adopted from time to time when a serious matter of this sort has to be dealt with.

MainHeading.P: Only a comparatively short time ago a complaint was made from these benches that three men whose names and addresses were given had been assaulted and beaten by C.I.D. men in the County Clare. The fact of the assault having been committed was denied by the Minister for Justice, but he did not stop there. The Minister said: “If there is any pretence of truth in that allegation, go to the courts.” The men went to the courts and they got damages. The allegation was made that a C.I.D. man assaulted a citizen here in this area in which we live. Again there was the suggestion “go to the courts.” He went to the courts, not like the Clare case for damages, but with a summons charging an offence against the C.I.D. The District Justice fined the C.I.D. man 40/-. There was an appeal to the Circuit Judge in this city and the Circuit Judge affirmed the conviction. In the case of these men they resorted to the courts because they accepted the invitation of the Minister for Justice. Now without argument and without excuse the Government take away from them that resort to the courts. They close and lock the doors of these courts.

It is said that that is being done because juries cannot be trusted. It was not a jury that inflicted the fine of 40/-. It was not a jury on appeal who affirmed that fine. Is it suggested that the District Justice was corrupt or had been intimidated? Is it suggested that the distinguished Circuit Court Judge who heard the appeal had in some fashion been intimidated? There is no such suggestion. Every possible fact and circumstance in favour of the defendants in the cases I have referred to were elicited by the able counsel who appeared for them. Yet the Judge gave damages or imposed a fine. That is one effect of acceptng an invitation from the Minister for Justice of the type that is made here “resort to Constitutional methods.” In that same Constitution there was placed an Article giving a Referendum to the people of this country, but when that Referendum was resorted to, the very fact of availing of it was made an excuse and an occasion to destroy it.

I ask the Deputies of this House quite seriously to consider whether the Constitution in piecemeal is being made a will-o'-the-wisp. The moment that you follow a piece of that Constitution, that moment it vanishes and evaporates. Yet the Minister for Justice yesterday had the coolness again to put forward a challenge of that sort.

I am not impressed by what I have heard from the opposite side as to the need of immediately effecting such a drastic change in the law and the legal procedure in this country. Why is all this being done in such a panicky way? Why is it all being rushed through in seventy-two hours? If there was this terrible need for immediate change of this fundamental character why were we not brought together a month ago? Why were we not brought together even a week ago? We have been referred here to a document going back as far as 1925. Why were we not summoned a week or a fortnight earlier and allowed an opportunity of calmly examining and understanding the Bill? A Bill of 34 clauses with appendices was handed around yesterday afternoon. I assume, of course, that the gentlemen on the benches opposite, endowed as they are with pellucid intellects, have mastered that Bill and all its implications in the very short time that is being made available. All I do say is that I have not been able to hear of any precedent for this Bill in any other Legislature in the world.

A careful examination of the Bill, even by a skilled and industrious official or Deputy, would require, not two days—it would require at least two weeks. Is that a fair way to treat this House? Is it a fair way to treat the people of this country? We have been told that it must be done; that, to use a phrase of, I think it was the Minister for Local Government—at all events it was from the Ministerial Bench—that trial by jury has been murdered. Now it is better that we should use language exactly. Trial by jury has not been murdered. In this country crime not associated with politics is punished with a celerity and with a thoroughness that is scarcely eclipsed in any other country; and ordinary crime is punished with the whole force of public opinion behind the authority that enforces punishment. Statistics show that we are not a crime-loving people as compared with other nations. Reference has been made here to the murder of Superintendent Curtin and to another murder —murders which every decent man in this country deplored. Those murderers have not been brought before a jury. If there had been an arrest for the murder of Superintendent Curtin; a public trial by a jury, and the evidence made available through the ordinary channels to the public; if that evidence seemed convincing, and if the jury appeared to fail in their duty, I certainly would reconsider my attitude towards jury trials in such cases. But that has not occurred. Are the public of this country satisfied that everything possible has been done to bring those criminals to justice? At all events, it is not the failure of the jury system that is responsible for leaving at large the murderer of Curtin or the murderer of Ryan.

Is the suggestion that if the people aimed at by this Bill are brought before the ordinary courts, that the ordinary machinery is not adequate or proper to deal with them? Of course if anyone is tried in the ordinary criminal court he is hedged around with certain safeguards as regards evidence. He cannot be convicted on mere gossip, mere hearsay. It is true that a court of criminal appeal may perhaps be availed of. Is there any real desire to get ride of that machinery and to substitute for it a tribunal or procedure whose decisions are not to be open to review? Is this House in this hurried way, and with so little reflection and so little consideration, to confer on this tribunal of three military officers, skilled, no doubt, in the arts of war, but who, from the nature of their profession and occupation, are not apt in the judicial functions—is this House to confer upon them a power the like of which has not been conferred upon High Court Judges, not to speak of Circuit Judges, from all of whom there is an appeal? What parallel is there for it?

As the time for debate is so very short I do not propose to state in detail the many objections that even a hasty reading of this Bill has led me to formulate. It was hasty, because although I have devoted a certain amount of attention to this Bill since I received it yesterday afternoon, I am conscious from its structure and such reading or attention as I have been able to give it that caution is necessary. On looking through the Bill I feel rather appalled. I feel that good advice would be to make haste slowly in regard to it. I do not like the idea of a court whose judgments or procedure are not open to any review in any respect, especially if it is a secret court. I do not like the idea of a court consisting entirely of men who have received no training as regards the law of evidence. I think that even in courtsmartial either under the Free State régime or under the British régime, in the more important cases, even the courtsmartial had amongst its members an officer who was a member of one or other branch of the legal profession. The proceedings in those serious cases were reviewed by a Judge. Advocate-General, a gentleman eminent and experienced in the legal profession. Why are these elementary safeguards being dispensed with? Why is this blank cheque being given as regards sentences? There is nothing here at all to insure that the punishment will in any way have any relation to the crime. Why have we Section 9? Section 9 is an extraordinary section. Apparently if the witness does not give the evidence which commends itself to the Tribunal as regards its truth, very direful results may follow. The Tribunal might very easily make a mistake in regard to the evidence that the witness has given, and I must say that I have been unable to find anything approaching a precedent for such a section as Clause 9. I have seen that some years ago under the Empire in one of the provinces of China there was a rule of law which approached, but did not fully reach the point that has been reached in Clause 9 of this Bill.

I ask the House to refuse a Second Reading to this Bill. I ask Deputies to refuse to give the advocates of physical force in this country a new argument. We have heard various statements and assertions made throughout this debate. All decent people are sick of the factions that infest this country. We hear of certain Ministers here having their private secret societies. We have heard of secret societies outside. These warring societies are each struggling for its own predominance. Should we not try to rid the country of all of them? Strong government is resorted to in many countries. There are countries where the Government is at least as strong and dignified as it is in this country. But in this country only the coat is trailed. If we draw attention to anything that is unhappy here, anything that may be provocative, and say that perhaps the temptation—call it what you like—to lawlessness should be removed, we are represented as encouraging crime. Why should jurymen be pestered over cases and why should any other tribunal be pestered over cases arising because certain people want to fly the Union Jack in this City when they know perfectly well that it is provocative and will cause trouble?

Speaker.P: The Deputy did not always think that.

Why should not public opinion express itself against that? That sort of thing is simply trailing the coat, looking for a fight. With the public opinion of the country behind the law, as I believe it would be behind the law if certain irritants like the Oath to the King of England were removed, the law would deal with these matters very strongly. We hear of Communism. I have tried in my constituency which I know very intimately—I do not know it merely as two counties; I know practically every parish in it—to get evidence of these Communistic activities. Perhaps it may be said that I am too hard to satisfy in regard to evidence, but I have tried to get it and I have obtained statements that purported to prove Communism and those statements on examination did not bear the slightest destructive criticism. They did not bear anything at all in the nature of cross-examination. They just seemed to fizzle out and the neares I could get was something to do with land. Anywhere I found anything approaching what might be called confiscation or Communism had to do with some area where the Land Commission had not fully operated and where the effects of land legislation had not fully penetrated.

MainHeading.P: People here seem to close their eyes to facts. The title to Irish land has often been assailed in the past. Most of the land of this country was confiscated once, a great deal of it was confiscated twice, and some of it was confiscated three times. You cannot draw too strong an inference from any feeling that may exist in a particular pocket of a parish where the land question has not been adjusted in the way the law of this State contemplates it will be adjusted. For these, amongst a number of other reasons that I have not time to adduce. I ask the House to refuse a Second Reading to this Bill.

Speaker.P: This debate has had all the evidence of unreality that the debate last night had. The same smoke-screens that were thrown across the path of the Dáil last night were thrown across to-day. It is unfortunate that the Government is so much afraid of discussion or have got the wind up to such an extent that they are afraid of a revolution on Friday night, that they cannot permit a full and adequate discussion on the Second Stage of the Bill, that I will be unable to comment at length on the speeches made here this evening, one of the most deplorable of which was the speech of Deputy Anthony. Since the time is so short, the most I can do is to described the Deputy's speech as treachery to the working classes. I will described the utterance he made to the effect that even at the sacrifice of limb and life he will be prepared to stand by this Bill as a faint shadow of the utterance of another Labour leader in this House in 1923, when he pledged the last man and the last shilling to crush the Republic. All I want to say at this stage, since no adequate discussion is permitted, is that, whether you like it or not, this issue will be settled outside your House by the ordinary common people of Ireland, and every Party that brands itself as guilty of creating this situation, and allowing this situation of manufacturing a revolution to develop, will have to bear its share of the guilt, and that guilt will not be light.
Question put: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time.”
The Dáil divided: Tá, 82; Níl, 66.
